snippet: The Internet of Things (IoT) is a network of tiny devices connected over the Internet to observe the physical world  gather data  and consciously act on it in a useful way. Billions of connected IoT devices are expected to bring a substantial added value for communities and for individuals  also in view of the fact that IoT is tightly connected with several well-known trends  such as Big Data  smart cities  and Industry 4.0  which promise to deeply change many aspects of our lives in the future. As an example  the unprecedented amount of data gathered by billions of IoT sensors will bring us the ability to get new insights and actionable intelligence regarding our world [1 2]. The pervasive presence of smart connected devices will enable the development of innovative services to improve our lives [3] and to face new and unexpected challenges  such as the COVID-19 outbreak [4]  and private and public objects (i.e.  things) will be available to anyone for renting  even for a short time  to support a new form of shared economy [5]. The general problem of giving a reward to subjects that contribute to this novel added value ecosystem is not only an economic or business-related question. Lately  IoT devices have not only been exchanging data; an emerging trend is to enable Machine-to-Machine (M2M) payments  turning each connected device into a platform for selling and purchasing. By 2022  451 Research’s IoT Market Monitor expects that USD 7.5 billion in new transactions will be driven  in the US  through IoT payments (https://www. forbes.com/sites/jordanmckee/2019/10/09/the-internet-of-payments-has-arrived/?sh= 6faa22da3e69  (accessed on 28 March 2022)). A typical IoT architecture consists of things  gateways  and the cloud platform (see Figure 2) [ 17]. Usually  things support power-efﬁcient wireless technologies (e.g.  Lo- RaWAN [18]  Sigfox [19]) that  in order to limit the energy consumption and prolong the network lifetime  do not allow direct connection to the Internet. In this scenario  gateways are more powerful devices  usually not bounded by energy constraints  in charge of re- ceiving the wireless communications from the things and delivering the messages to the cloud platform over the Internet.

Milestones in DeFi Development in the U.S. The evolution of Decentralized Finance (DeFi) in the United States is a testament to the dynamic interplay between  technological innovation and financial services. The journey of DeFi  from its nascent stages to becoming a significant  part of the financial landscape  is marked by several key milestones that reflect its growing impact and integration into  the broader economy. The early stages of DeFi's development coincided with the advent of blockchain technology and the introduction of  Bitcoin in 2008. However  it was the launch of Ethereum in 2015  with its groundbreaking smart contract capabilities   that truly set the stage for the DeFi revolution. The United States  known for its innovative spirit and technological  prowess  quickly emerged as a fertile  ground for the growth and development of DeFi applications. Protocols such as  MakerDAO  Compound  and Uniswap gained prominence  offering decentralized services like lending  borrowing  and  trading  which challenged traditional financial models by elimina ting intermediaries (Umarov  Umarov  & Umarov   2022). A pivotal moment in DeFi's journey was its increasing integration with traditional financial systems. Major financial  institutions in the U.S. began to recognize the potential of blockchain technology i n transforming finance. This  integration marked a shift in perception  positioning DeFi not just as an alternative but as a complementary component  of the broader financial ecosystem. This period saw significant investments from traditional financial entit ies into DeFi  projects  signaling a blending of the old with the new (Ozili  2022). Technological advancements and innovations have been at the heart of DeFi's growth in the U.S. Innovations such as  yield farming  liquidity mining  and the introduction of governance tokens have not only attracted a broader user base  but have also enhanced the functionality and efficiency of DeFi services. These innovations reflect the sector's  commitment to evolving and adapting to user needs and market dynamics (Umarov  Um arov  & Umarov  2022). The Ethereum Merge  which marked the transition of the Ethereum blockchain from proof -of-work (PoW) to proof-of- stake (PoS)  was another significant milestone for DeFi.

snippet: US Hybrid Consensus is a protocol that combines some classical consensus protocols. ByzCoin [25] proposes a two-phase protocol based on the idea of Bitcoin-NG [15]. However  it is able to ensure strong consistency by combining PoW and PBFT. In addition  ByzCoin uses a collective signing protocol called Cosi [71] to reduce the cost of the prepare and commit phases of PBFT and scale it to large consensus groups. Later works such as Hybrid consensus [72]  Solidus [73] also propose to combine different protocols with PoW aiming to improve on the throughput and security. Algorand [16] is a cryptocurrency based on a Byzantine Agreement (BA) protocol. By combining with V eriﬁable Random Functions [74]  users are chosen to become a com- mittee member to participate in the BA and reach consensus on the next set of transactions. To mitigate targeted attacks  the participant will be replaced after sending a message in BA. With all these approaches  Algorand scales to 500 000 users in experiments and achieves high throughput. f: OTHER CONSENSUS Some other new consensus algorithms have been proposed in recent years  including PoA (proof-of-authority) [75]  PoC (proof of capacity) [76] and PoP (proof-of-Participation) [77]  which make some modiﬁcations of the previous con- sensus to improve the scalability of blockchain. PoP (Proof of Participation) is a new protocol that imple- ments PoS through the mining mechanism of PoW. PoP selects a list of stakeholders to work out a computational task  which is simpler than that in PoW  to generate a new block. Other stakeholders who did not participate in the mining validate the block and propagate it. Unlike PoS  transaction fees in PoP are only distributed to stakeholders participat- ing in validation and propagation  which thus encourages stakeholders to maintain an online node and sustain the sys- tem. PoP includes two layers of security  proof-of-work  and proof-of-stake  that protect the system from security prob- lems (e.g. double-spending) and also consume less energy than the traditional PoW mechanism. PoC (Proof of Capacity) is a consensus algorithm that uti- lizes the storage resource (disk space) to mine.

DeFi uses a multi-layered architecture. Every layer has a distinct role. The layers are built on top of each other  resulting in an open and highly composable infrastructure that anyone can build on  rehash  or use. Here are the different layers of the DeFi stack [21]  [6]  for example: - The settlement layer allows the network to securely store ownership data and guarantees that any state changes adhere to its set of rules. - The asset layer: This category includes all assets issued on top of the settlement layer. snippet: 1.1. Unveiling the Concept of Decentralized Finance (DeFi).  Decentralized Finance (DeFi) represents a paradigm shift in the financial sector  moving away from traditional   centralized systems towards a more open  transparent  and accessible framework. This innovative concept  primarily  built on the Ethereum platform  offers an alternative to conventional financial infrastructure  leveraging blockchain  technology to democratize financial services (Umarov  Umarov  & Umarov  2022). World Journal of Advanced Research and Reviews  2024  21(01)  2313–2328  2314  At its core  DeFi is a system where financial products become available on a public decentralized blockchain network   making them open to anyone to use  rather than going through intermediaries like banks or brokerages (dos Santos et  al.  2022). Unlike traditional finance  DeFi is characterized by its open -source nature  immutable transactions  and lack  of centralized control. This means that DeFi platforms operate without a central authority  using smart contracts - self- executing contracts with the terms of the agreement directly written into code. The emergence of DeFi can be traced back to the development of blockchain technology and the introduction of Bitcoin  in 2008  which laid the foundation for decentralized financial systems. However  it was the launch of Ethereum in 2015   a Turing -complete blockchain that significantl y expanded the scope of blockchain -based financial systems beyond  simple cryptocurrency transactions (dos Santos et al.  2022). Ethereum's introduction of smart contracts enabled the  creation of more complex financial services  such as lending  borrowing  and yield farming  all operating in a trustless  environment. DeFi's growth has been meteoric  with the total value locked (TVL) in DeFi protocols surging from a mere $4 billion to  over $100 billion in just a few years  reflecting its increasing popularity and the growing trust in its underlying  technology (Jensen  von Wachter  & Ross  2021). This explosive growth can be attributed to several factors  including  the transparency of blockchain technology  the potential for higher returns compared to traditiona l banking  and the  inclusivity and accessibility of DeFi platforms. One of the most significant advantages of DeFi is its potential to offer financial services to the unbanked and  underbanked populations.

This  integration marked a shift in perception  positioning DeFi not just as an alternative but as a complementary component  of the broader financial ecosystem. To mitigate targeted attacks  the participant will be replaced after sending a message in BA. With all these approaches  Algorand scales to 500 000 users in experiments and achieves high throughput. f: OTHER CONSENSUS Some other new consensus algorithms have been proposed in recent years  including PoA (proof-of-authority) [75]  PoC (proof of capacity) [76] and PoP (proof-of-Participation) [77]  which make some modiﬁcations of the previous con- sensus to improve the scalability of blockchain. PoP (Proof of Participation) is a new protocol that imple- ments PoS through the mining mechanism of PoW. PoP selects a list of stakeholders to work out a computational task  which is simpler than that in PoW  to generate a new block. Other stakeholders who did not participate in the mining validate the block and propagate it. Unlike PoS  transaction fees in PoP are only distributed to stakeholders participat- ing in validation and propagation  which thus encourages stakeholders to maintain an online node and sustain the sys- tem. PoP includes two layers of security  proof-of-work  and proof-of-stake  that protect the system from security prob- lems (e.g. double-spending) and also consume less energy than the traditional PoW mechanism. PoC (Proof of Capacity) is a consensus algorithm that uti- lizes the storage resource (disk space) to mine.

snippet: 1.1. Unveiling the Concept of Decentralized Finance (DeFi).  Decentralized Finance (DeFi) represents a paradigm shift in the financial sector  moving away from traditional   centralized systems towards a more open  transparent  and accessible framework. This innovative concept  primarily  built on the Ethereum platform  offers an alternative to conventional financial infrastructure  leveraging blockchain  technology to democratize financial services (Umarov  Umarov  & Umarov  2022). World Journal of Advanced Research and Reviews  2024  21(01)  2313–2328  2314  At its core  DeFi is a system where financial products become available on a public decentralized blockchain network   making them open to anyone to use  rather than going through intermediaries like banks or brokerages (dos Santos et  al.  2022). Unlike traditional finance  DeFi is characterized by its open -source nature  immutable transactions  and lack  of centralized control. This means that DeFi platforms operate without a central authority  using smart contracts - self- executing contracts with the terms of the agreement directly written into code. The emergence of DeFi can be traced back to the development of blockchain technology and the introduction of Bitcoin  in 2008  which laid the foundation for decentralized financial systems. However  it was the launch of Ethereum in 2015   a Turing -complete blockchain that significantl y expanded the scope of blockchain -based financial systems beyond  simple cryptocurrency transactions (dos Santos et al.  2022). Ethereum's introduction of smart contracts enabled the  creation of more complex financial services  such as lending  borrowing  and yield farming  all operating in a trustless  environment. DeFi's growth has been meteoric  with the total value locked (TVL) in DeFi protocols surging from a mere $4 billion to  over $100 billion in just a few years  reflecting its increasing popularity and the growing trust in its underlying  technology (Jensen  von Wachter  & Ross  2021). This explosive growth can be attributed to several factors  including  the transparency of blockchain technology  the potential for higher returns compared to traditiona l banking  and the  inclusivity and accessibility of DeFi platforms. One of the most significant advantages of DeFi is its potential to offer financial services to the unbanked and  underbanked populations.

The journey of DeFi  from its nascent stages to becoming a significant  part of the financial landscape  is marked by several key milestones that reflect its growing impact and integration into  the broader economy. The early stages of DeFi's development coincided with the advent of blockchain technology and the introduction of  Bitcoin in 2008. However  it was the launch of Ethereum in 2015  with its groundbreaking smart contract capabilities   that truly set the stage for the DeFi revolution. The United States  known for its innovative spirit and technological  prowess  quickly emerged as a fertile  ground for the growth and development of DeFi applications. Protocols such as  MakerDAO  Compound  and Uniswap gained prominence  offering decentralized services like lending  borrowing  and  trading  which challenged traditional financial models by elimina ting intermediaries (Umarov  Umarov  & Umarov   2022). A pivotal moment in DeFi's journey was its increasing integration with traditional financial systems. Major financial  institutions in the U.S. began to recognize the potential of blockchain technology i n transforming finance. This  integration marked a shift in perception  positioning DeFi not just as an alternative but as a complementary component  of the broader financial ecosystem. This period saw significant investments from traditional financial entit ies into DeFi  projects  signaling a blending of the old with the new (Ozili  2022). Technological advancements and innovations have been at the heart of DeFi's growth in the U.S. Innovations such as  yield farming  liquidity mining  and the introduction of governance tokens have not only attracted a broader user base  but have also enhanced the functionality and efficiency of DeFi services. These innovations reflect the sector's  commitment to evolving and adapting to user needs and market dynamics (Umarov  Um arov  & Umarov  2022). The Ethereum Merge  which marked the transition of the Ethereum blockchain from proof -of-work (PoW) to proof-of- stake (PoS)  was another significant milestone for DeFi.

snippet: 1.1. Unveiling the Concept of Decentralized Finance (DeFi).  Decentralized Finance (DeFi) represents a paradigm shift in the financial sector  moving away from traditional   centralized systems towards a more open  transparent  and accessible framework. This innovative concept  primarily  built on the Ethereum platform  offers an alternative to conventional financial infrastructure  leveraging blockchain  technology to democratize financial services (Umarov  Umarov  & Umarov  2022). World Journal of Advanced Research and Reviews  2024  21(01)  2313–2328  2314  At its core  DeFi is a system where financial products become available on a public decentralized blockchain network   making them open to anyone to use  rather than going through intermediaries like banks or brokerages (dos Santos et  al.  2022). Unlike traditional finance  DeFi is characterized by its open -source nature  immutable transactions  and lack  of centralized control. This means that DeFi platforms operate without a central authority  using smart contracts - self- executing contracts with the terms of the agreement directly written into code. The emergence of DeFi can be traced back to the development of blockchain technology and the introduction of Bitcoin  in 2008  which laid the foundation for decentralized financial systems. However  it was the launch of Ethereum in 2015   a Turing -complete blockchain that significantl y expanded the scope of blockchain -based financial systems beyond  simple cryptocurrency transactions (dos Santos et al.  2022). Ethereum's introduction of smart contracts enabled the  creation of more complex financial services  such as lending  borrowing  and yield farming  all operating in a trustless  environment. DeFi's growth has been meteoric  with the total value locked (TVL) in DeFi protocols surging from a mere $4 billion to  over $100 billion in just a few years  reflecting its increasing popularity and the growing trust in its underlying  technology (Jensen  von Wachter  & Ross  2021). This explosive growth can be attributed to several factors  including  the transparency of blockchain technology  the potential for higher returns compared to traditiona l banking  and the  inclusivity and accessibility of DeFi platforms. One of the most significant advantages of DeFi is its potential to offer financial services to the unbanked and  underbanked populations.

The journey of DeFi  from its nascent stages to becoming a significant  part of the financial landscape  is marked by several key milestones that reflect its growing impact and integration into  the broader economy. The early stages of DeFi's development coincided with the advent of blockchain technology and the introduction of  Bitcoin in 2008. The United States  known for its innovative spirit and technological  prowess  quickly emerged as a fertile  ground for the growth and development of DeFi applications. A pivotal moment in DeFi's journey was its increasing integration with traditional financial systems. Major financial  institutions in the U.S. began to recognize the potential of blockchain technology i n transforming finance. This  integration marked a shift in perception  positioning DeFi not just as an alternative but as a complementary component  of the broader financial ecosystem. This period saw significant investments from traditional financial entit ies into DeFi  projects  signaling a blending of the old with the new (Ozili  2022). Technological advancements and innovations have been at the heart of DeFi's growth in the U.S. Innovations such as  yield farming  liquidity mining  and the introduction of governance tokens have not only attracted a broader user base  but have also enhanced the functionality and efficiency of DeFi services. snippet: US Hybrid Consensus is a protocol that combines some classical consensus protocols. ByzCoin [25] proposes a two-phase protocol based on the idea of Bitcoin-NG [15]. However  it is able to ensure strong consistency by combining PoW and PBFT. In addition  ByzCoin uses a collective signing protocol called Cosi [71] to reduce the cost of the prepare and commit phases of PBFT and scale it to large consensus groups. Later works such as Hybrid consensus [72]  Solidus [73] also propose to combine different protocols with PoW aiming to improve on the throughput and security. Algorand [16] is a cryptocurrency based on a Byzantine Agreement (BA) protocol. By combining with V eriﬁable Random Functions [74]  users are chosen to become a com- mittee member to participate in the BA and reach consensus on the next set of transactions. To mitigate targeted attacks  the participant will be replaced after sending a message in BA. With all these approaches  Algorand scales to 500 000 users in experiments and achieves high throughput. f: OTHER CONSENSUS Some other new consensus algorithms have been proposed in recent years  including PoA (proof-of-authority) [75]  PoC (proof of capacity) [76] and PoP (proof-of-Participation) [77]  which make some modiﬁcations of the previous con- sensus to improve the scalability of blockchain. PoP (Proof of Participation) is a new protocol that imple- ments PoS through the mining mechanism of PoW. PoP selects a list of stakeholders to work out a computational task  which is simpler than that in PoW  to generate a new block. Other stakeholders who did not participate in the mining validate the block and propagate it. Unlike PoS  transaction fees in PoP are only distributed to stakeholders participat- ing in validation and propagation  which thus encourages stakeholders to maintain an online node and sustain the sys- tem. PoP includes two layers of security  proof-of-work  and proof-of-stake  that protect the system from security prob- lems (e.g. double-spending) and also consume less energy than the traditional PoW mechanism. PoC (Proof of Capacity) is a consensus algorithm that uti- lizes the storage resource (disk space) to mine.

Here are the different layers of the DeFi stack [21]  [6]  for example: - The settlement layer allows the network to securely store ownership data and guarantees that any state changes adhere to its set of rules. - The asset layer: This category includes all assets issued on top of the settlement layer. Decentralized exchanges are typically facilitators of such transactions by offering a bookkeeping system that matches buyers and sellers. Although decentralized exchanges running in heteroge- neous DLTs are appearing [95]  the mechanisms used for interoperation are classified as oracles.

title: Decentralized Finance (DEFI) in the U. S. economy: A review: Assessing the rise, challenges, and implications of blockchain-driven financial systems.
snippet: 1.1. Unveiling the Concept of Decentralized Finance (DeFi).  Decentralized Finance (DeFi) represents a paradigm shift in the financial sector  moving away from traditional   centralized systems towards a more open  transparent  and accessible framework. This innovative concept  primarily  built on the Ethereum platform  offers an alternative to conventional financial infrastructure  leveraging blockchain  technology to democratize financial services (Umarov  Umarov  & Umarov  2022). World Journal of Advanced Research and Reviews  2024  21(01)  2313–2328  2314  At its core  DeFi is a system where financial products become available on a public decentralized blockchain network   making them open to anyone to use  rather than going through intermediaries like banks or brokerages (dos Santos et  al.  2022). Unlike traditional finance  DeFi is characterized by its open -source nature  immutable transactions  and lack  of centralized control. This means that DeFi platforms operate without a central authority  using smart contracts - self- executing contracts with the terms of the agreement directly written into code. The emergence of DeFi can be traced back to the development of blockchain technology and the introduction of Bitcoin  in 2008  which laid the foundation for decentralized financial systems. However  it was the launch of Ethereum in 2015   a Turing -complete blockchain that significantl y expanded the scope of blockchain -based financial systems beyond  simple cryptocurrency transactions (dos Santos et al.  2022). Ethereum's introduction of smart contracts enabled the  creation of more complex financial services  such as lending  borrowing  and yield farming  all operating in a trustless  environment. DeFi's growth has been meteoric  with the total value locked (TVL) in DeFi protocols surging from a mere $4 billion to  over $100 billion in just a few years  reflecting its increasing popularity and the growing trust in its underlying  technology (Jensen  von Wachter  & Ross  2021). This explosive growth can be attributed to several factors  including  the transparency of blockchain technology  the potential for higher returns compared to traditiona l banking  and the  inclusivity and accessibility of DeFi platforms. One of the most significant advantages of DeFi is its potential to offer financial services to the unbanked and  underbanked populations.

The journey of DeFi  from its nascent stages to becoming a significant  part of the financial landscape  is marked by several key milestones that reflect its growing impact and integration into  the broader economy. The early stages of DeFi's development coincided with the advent of blockchain technology and the introduction of  Bitcoin in 2008. The United States  known for its innovative spirit and technological  prowess  quickly emerged as a fertile  ground for the growth and development of DeFi applications. Protocols such as  MakerDAO  Compound  and Uniswap gained prominence  offering decentralized services like lending  borrowing  and  trading  which challenged traditional financial models by elimina ting intermediaries (Umarov  Umarov  & Umarov   2022). A pivotal moment in DeFi's journey was its increasing integration with traditional financial systems. Major financial  institutions in the U.S. began to recognize the potential of blockchain technology i n transforming finance. This  integration marked a shift in perception  positioning DeFi not just as an alternative but as a complementary component  of the broader financial ecosystem. This period saw significant investments from traditional financial entit ies into DeFi  projects  signaling a blending of the old with the new (Ozili  2022). Technological advancements and innovations have been at the heart of DeFi's growth in the U.S. Innovations such as  yield farming  liquidity mining  and the introduction of governance tokens have not only attracted a broader user base  but have also enhanced the functionality and efficiency of DeFi services. Lately  IoT devices have not only been exchanging data; an emerging trend is to enable Machine-to-Machine (M2M) payments  turning each connected device into a platform for selling and purchasing. By 2022  451 Research’s IoT Market Monitor expects that USD 7.5 billion in new transactions will be driven  in the US  through IoT payments (https://www. forbes.com/sites/jordanmckee/2019/10/09/the-internet-of-payments-has-arrived/?sh= 6faa22da3e69  (accessed on 28 March 2022)). A typical IoT architecture consists of things  gateways  and the cloud platform (see Figure 2) [ 17]. Usually  things support power-efﬁcient wireless technologies (e.g.  Lo- RaWAN [18]  Sigfox [19]) that  in order to limit the energy consumption and prolong the network lifetime  do not allow direct connection to the Internet. snippet: US Hybrid Consensus is a protocol that combines some classical consensus protocols. ByzCoin [25] proposes a two-phase protocol based on the idea of Bitcoin-NG [15]. However  it is able to ensure strong consistency by combining PoW and PBFT. In addition  ByzCoin uses a collective signing protocol called Cosi [71] to reduce the cost of the prepare and commit phases of PBFT and scale it to large consensus groups. Later works such as Hybrid consensus [72]  Solidus [73] also propose to combine different protocols with PoW aiming to improve on the throughput and security. Algorand [16] is a cryptocurrency based on a Byzantine Agreement (BA) protocol. By combining with V eriﬁable Random Functions [74]  users are chosen to become a com- mittee member to participate in the BA and reach consensus on the next set of transactions. To mitigate targeted attacks  the participant will be replaced after sending a message in BA. With all these approaches  Algorand scales to 500 000 users in experiments and achieves high throughput. f: OTHER CONSENSUS Some other new consensus algorithms have been proposed in recent years  including PoA (proof-of-authority) [75]  PoC (proof of capacity) [76] and PoP (proof-of-Participation) [77]  which make some modiﬁcations of the previous con- sensus to improve the scalability of blockchain. PoP (Proof of Participation) is a new protocol that imple- ments PoS through the mining mechanism of PoW. PoP selects a list of stakeholders to work out a computational task  which is simpler than that in PoW  to generate a new block. Other stakeholders who did not participate in the mining validate the block and propagate it. Unlike PoS  transaction fees in PoP are only distributed to stakeholders participat- ing in validation and propagation  which thus encourages stakeholders to maintain an online node and sustain the sys- tem. PoP includes two layers of security  proof-of-work  and proof-of-stake  that protect the system from security prob- lems (e.g. double-spending) and also consume less energy than the traditional PoW mechanism. PoC (Proof of Capacity) is a consensus algorithm that uti- lizes the storage resource (disk space) to mine.

title: Decentralized Finance (DEFI) in the U. S. economy: A review: Assessing the rise, challenges, and implications of blockchain-driven financial systems.
snippet: 1.1. Unveiling the Concept of Decentralized Finance (DeFi).  Decentralized Finance (DeFi) represents a paradigm shift in the financial sector  moving away from traditional   centralized systems towards a more open  transparent  and accessible framework. This innovative concept  primarily  built on the Ethereum platform  offers an alternative to conventional financial infrastructure  leveraging blockchain  technology to democratize financial services (Umarov  Umarov  & Umarov  2022). World Journal of Advanced Research and Reviews  2024  21(01)  2313–2328  2314  At its core  DeFi is a system where financial products become available on a public decentralized blockchain network   making them open to anyone to use  rather than going through intermediaries like banks or brokerages (dos Santos et  al.  2022). Unlike traditional finance  DeFi is characterized by its open -source nature  immutable transactions  and lack  of centralized control. This means that DeFi platforms operate without a central authority  using smart contracts - self- executing contracts with the terms of the agreement directly written into code. The emergence of DeFi can be traced back to the development of blockchain technology and the introduction of Bitcoin  in 2008  which laid the foundation for decentralized financial systems. However  it was the launch of Ethereum in 2015   a Turing -complete blockchain that significantl y expanded the scope of blockchain -based financial systems beyond  simple cryptocurrency transactions (dos Santos et al.  2022). Ethereum's introduction of smart contracts enabled the  creation of more complex financial services  such as lending  borrowing  and yield farming  all operating in a trustless  environment. DeFi's growth has been meteoric  with the total value locked (TVL) in DeFi protocols surging from a mere $4 billion to  over $100 billion in just a few years  reflecting its increasing popularity and the growing trust in its underlying  technology (Jensen  von Wachter  & Ross  2021). This explosive growth can be attributed to several factors  including  the transparency of blockchain technology  the potential for higher returns compared to traditiona l banking  and the  inclusivity and accessibility of DeFi platforms. One of the most significant advantages of DeFi is its potential to offer financial services to the unbanked and  underbanked populations.

Milestones in DeFi Development in the U.S. The evolution of Decentralized Finance (DeFi) in the United States is a testament to the dynamic interplay between  technological innovation and financial services. The journey of DeFi  from its nascent stages to becoming a significant  part of the financial landscape  is marked by several key milestones that reflect its growing impact and integration into  the broader economy. The early stages of DeFi's development coincided with the advent of blockchain technology and the introduction of  Bitcoin in 2008. However  it was the launch of Ethereum in 2015  with its groundbreaking smart contract capabilities   that truly set the stage for the DeFi revolution. The United States  known for its innovative spirit and technological  prowess  quickly emerged as a fertile  ground for the growth and development of DeFi applications. Protocols such as  MakerDAO  Compound  and Uniswap gained prominence  offering decentralized services like lending  borrowing  and  trading  which challenged traditional financial models by elimina ting intermediaries (Umarov  Umarov  & Umarov   2022). A pivotal moment in DeFi's journey was its increasing integration with traditional financial systems. Major financial  institutions in the U.S. began to recognize the potential of blockchain technology i n transforming finance. This  integration marked a shift in perception  positioning DeFi not just as an alternative but as a complementary component  of the broader financial ecosystem. This period saw significant investments from traditional financial entit ies into DeFi  projects  signaling a blending of the old with the new (Ozili  2022). Technological advancements and innovations have been at the heart of DeFi's growth in the U.S. Innovations such as  yield farming  liquidity mining  and the introduction of governance tokens have not only attracted a broader user base  but have also enhanced the functionality and efficiency of DeFi services. These innovations reflect the sector's  commitment to evolving and adapting to user needs and market dynamics (Umarov  Um arov  & Umarov  2022). The Ethereum Merge  which marked the transition of the Ethereum blockchain from proof -of-work (PoW) to proof-of- stake (PoS)  was another significant milestone for DeFi.

The amount of IoT devices is rapidly increasing. By 2025  forecasts suggest that there will be more than 75 billion IoT-connected devices in use  which is three times those deployed in 2019 (https://www.statista.com/statistics/471264/iot-number-of-connected- devices-worldwide/  (accessed on 28 March 2022)). The unprecedented amount of data collected by the IoT on the physical world  combined with cloud computing  promotes the development of new services  affecting many aspects of human daily life and with great market potential. Typical areas of application include manufacturing  smart city  supply chain  transportation  agriculture  energy management  environmental monitoring  and many others [16]. Lately  IoT devices have not only been exchanging data; an emerging trend is to enable Machine-to-Machine (M2M) payments  turning each connected device into a platform for selling and purchasing. By 2022  451 Research’s IoT Market Monitor expects that USD 7.5 billion in new transactions will be driven  in the US  through IoT payments (https://www. forbes.com/sites/jordanmckee/2019/10/09/the-internet-of-payments-has-arrived/?sh= 6faa22da3e69  (accessed on 28 March 2022)). A typical IoT architecture consists of things  gateways  and the cloud platform (see Figure 2) [ 17]. Usually  things support power-efﬁcient wireless technologies (e.g.  Lo- RaWAN [18]  Sigfox [19]) that  in order to limit the energy consumption and prolong the network lifetime  do not allow direct connection to the Internet. In this scenario  gateways are more powerful devices  usually not bounded by energy constraints  in charge of re- ceiving the wireless communications from the things and delivering the messages to the cloud platform over the Internet.
